description: Inherited from Middle English engreynen, from the French phrase en grain; reinforced by the phrase (dyed) in grain. See grain.

entries.meaning: Dyed before manufacture; said of the material of a textile fabric; hence, in general, thoroughly inwrought; forming an essential part of the substance.
examples: When were such changes ever made in men's natural relations to one another: when was such reconcilement of ingrain differences ever effected!

entries.meaning: An ingrain fabric, such as a carpet.

verbs.description: ingrain (third-person singular simple present ingrains, present participle ingraining, simple past and past participle ingrained)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To dye with a fast or lasting colour.
(transitive, figuratively) To make (something) deeply part of something else.
examples: Synonyms: breed in the bone, embed, infix, instill, radicate
The dirt was deeply ingrained in the carpet.
The lessons I learned at school were firmly ingrained in my mind.
